net.jbasics.util

Class Numbers

  • java.lang.Object
    • net.jbasics.util.Numbers

  • public final class Numbers
extends Object

    Math Helper Routines

        // Add two numbers, returning a default value if an error encountered:
    final double result1 = Numbers.add(double1, double2, defaultValueOnError);

    // Take square root of number, returning a default value on error:
    final double result2 = Numbers.sqrt(double1, defaultValueOnError);

    // Determine if two numbers "equal" within a given epsilon:
    final boolean areEqual = Numbers.areEqual(double1, double2, 0.0001);
    Since:
    1.0
    Version:
    2020-01-26
    Author:
    Rob Stoecklein

    • Method Detail

      • areEqual

        public static boolean areEqual(long value1,
                               long value2)
        Determine if two long integer values are equal.

        Of course this doesn't provide a lot of simplification, as the caller could simply write if (long1 == long2). This method is here, instead, to protect the case where the caller perhaps doesn't realize or know that the passed parameters are long values. In certain high-value situations, the call to areEqual(double, double) fails when using longs because a long has more signficant digits than a double.

        Returns:
        true if x == y, otherwise false

      • areEqual

        public static boolean areEqual(double x,
                               double y)
        Determine if two floating point values are essentially the same (uses epsilon = 1.0e-11)
        Returns:
        true if x == y within 1e-11, false otherwise
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        areEqual(double, double, double)

      • areEqual

        public static boolean areEqual(double x,
                               double y,
                               double epsilon)
        Determines if two floating-point values are equal within the given epsilon. 
            Numbers.areEqual(0.0, 0.0, 0.0)                      = true
    Numbers.areEqual(1, 2, 1)                            = true
    Numbers.areEqual(123.4567891, 123.4567892, 0.000001) = true
    Numbers.areEqual(123.456789, 123.456790, 0.000001)   = true
    Numbers.areEqual(-8.765, -8.764, 0.0011)             = true
    Numbers.areEqual(1, 3, 1)                            = false
    Numbers.areEqual(123.456789, 123.456790, 0.0000001)  = false
    Numbers.areEqual(-8.765, -8.764, 0.001)              = false
        Parameters:
        x - value1
        y - value2
        epsilon - the delta to use to compare if x is essentially equal to y
        Returns:
        true if x is within epsilon of y
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        Precision.compareTo(double, double, double)

        Divide two values. If the result is NaN or Infinite, then return the default.
        Parameters:
        value1 - dividend
        value2 - divisor
        defaultValue - value to return if the division operation results in an invalid value
        Returns:
        result of (dividend / divisor)
        Since:
